content: The Act may be cited as the "Port Authority of New York/New Jersey Port Security Task Force Implementation Act of 2008" and includes a table of contents. The "Port Authority of New York/New Jersey Port Security Task Force Implementation Act of 2008" includes provisions for secure international intermodal transportation systems, regional recovery plans, national tactical plans, risk-based resource allocation, maritime security risk assessment, integration of security plans with local authorities, advanced notice for Coast Guard inspections, fraudulent transportation worker identification cards, federal licensing of ship agents, security individual establishment, certification of maritime security guards, and grants for tier 1 and tier 2 ports. Sec. 14 requires regional strategic risk management assessment for tier 1 and tier 2 ports. Sec. 15 mandates vessel security plans for supply and similar vessels. SEC. 2. SECURE SYSTEMS OF INTERNATIONAL INTERMODAL TRANSPORTATION. Section 70116 of title 46, United States Code is amended to ensure the security and integrity of shipments of goods to the United States and facilitate their movement through an expedited security and clearance program. Within one year of the enactment of the Port Authority of New York/New Jersey Port Security Task Force Implementation Act of 2008, the Secretary will implement program elements through the Commissioner of Customs and Border Protection. The Commissioner of Customs and Border Protection will establish standards for verifying and sealing cargo containers, securing and monitoring cargo in transit, enhancing physical security of shipping containers, and screening cargo before loading in a foreign port. The Commissioner of Customs and Border Protection will establish standards for verifying and sealing cargo containers, securing and monitoring cargo in transit, enhancing physical security of shipping containers, and screening cargo before loading in a foreign port. Additionally, requirements for entry of containers into the United States will be enforced to ensure compliance with security measures for international intermodal transport movements. The Commissioner of Customs and Border Protection will establish standards for verifying and sealing cargo containers, securing and monitoring cargo in transit, enhancing physical security of shipping containers, and screening cargo before loading in a foreign port. Containers arriving directly or via a foreign port must comply with these standards and procedures. SEC. 3. REGIONAL RECOVERY PLANS. Establishment of regional response and recovery protocols for transportation security incidents in accordance with relevant laws. Coordination of plans for effective response and recovery efforts. It emphasizes the importance of consistency with various national security initiatives. The National Tactical Plan must be shared with Area Maritime Security Committees for regional and local planning and exercises. Risk-based resource allocation is also emphasized. The Secretary of the department in which the Coast Guard operates must develop a national standard for prioritizing security risks at US ports within a year. This standard will be used by Maritime Security Committees to evaluate and mitigate risks at ports within two years. The Secretary must develop a national standard for prioritizing security risks at US ports, which will be used for resource allocations and grant-making decisions. The Secretary of the department in which the Coast Guard operates must make the Maritime Security Risk Assessment Model tool available to regulated vessels and facilities for conducting risk assessments. Additionally, there will be Maritime and Cargo Security Integrated Project Teams established. SEC. 7. MARITIME AND CARGO SECURITY INTEGRATED PROJECT TEAMS. The Secretary of Homeland Security will establish integrated project teams within the science and technology directorate to assist in cargo security research, development, and acquisition activities, with participation from port authorities or state agencies. SEC. 8. INTEGRATION OF SECURITY PLANS AND SYSTEMS WITH LOCAL PORT AUTHORITY AND LAW ENFORCEMENT AGENCIES. Section 70102 of title 46, United States Code is amended to require facility owners to share vulnerability assessments with port authorities and law enforcement agencies, and integrate security systems with compatible systems operated by these entities. The Commandant of the Coast Guard must establish a policy within 90 days for advance notice before boarding vessels for ISPS compliance or Port State Control inspection. SEC. 10 amends Section 70105 of title 46, United States Code, allowing law enforcement to confiscate fraudulent or tampered Transportation Worker Identification Cards. SEC. 11 introduces federal licensing of ship agents. Within a year of this Act's enactment, the Federal Maritime Commission will establish a procedure for training, certifying, and licensing steamship agents in the US. Individuals must hold a valid transportation security card to receive a license. Acting as a vessel agent without a valid license and transportation security card will be unlawful. The Federal Maritime Commission will establish a procedure for certifying and licensing steamship agents in the US. Violation of the licensing requirement is punishable by imprisonment for up to 1 year and a fine under title 18, United States Code. SEC. 12. ESTABLISHMENT OF A SECURITY INDIVIDUAL. Vessels must designate a US person to respond to security incidents in US ports and notify relevant authorities. SEC. 13. CERTIFICATION OF MARITIME SECURITY GUARDS. SEC. 13. CERTIFICATION OF MARITIME SECURITY GUARDS. The Secretary must ensure that all maritime security guards meet training standards in security procedures and hazardous materials handling. The Secretary shall establish regional strategic risk management priorities for tier 1 and tier 2 ports and consider them in awarding grants. Vessel security plans for supply vessels are amended to include TWICs for crew members. Effective date for amendments is 1 year after enactment of the Act.
